title: Acts Chapter 10 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 10 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 10 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 10.

questions.question: Who was Cornelius according to Acts 10:1?
options: A centurion of the Italian band
A fisherman from Galilee
A priest in Jerusalem
A tax collector in Caesarea
questions.correctAnswer: A centurion of the Italian band
questions.explanation: Acts 10:1 states that Cornelius was a centurion of the band called the Italian band.

questions.question: What kind of man was Cornelius described as in Acts 10:2?
options: A devout man who feared God and gave alms
A wealthy merchant with many servants
A rebellious soldier
A teacher of the law
questions.correctAnswer: A devout man who feared God and gave alms
questions.explanation: Acts 10:2 describes Cornelius as a devout man who feared God with all his house, gave much alms, and prayed always.

questions.question: At what hour of the day did Cornelius see an angel in a vision (Acts 10:3)?
options: The ninth hour
The sixth hour
The third hour
The twelfth hour
questions.correctAnswer: The ninth hour
questions.explanation: Acts 10:3 states the vision occurred about the ninth hour of the day.

questions.question: What did the angel tell Cornelius about his prayers and alms in Acts 10:4?
options: They are come up for a memorial before God
They were not accepted
They must be doubled
They were forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: They are come up for a memorial before God
questions.explanation: Acts 10:4 explains the angel said Cornelius's prayers and alms are remembered before God.

questions.question: Who was Cornelius instructed to send for in Acts 10:5?
options: Simon Peter
John the Baptist
Paul the Apostle
Stephen the Deacon
questions.correctAnswer: Simon Peter
questions.explanation: Acts 10:5 commands Cornelius to send men to Joppa to call for Simon, whose surname is Peter.

questions.question: Where was Simon Peter lodging when Cornelius sent for him (Acts 10:6)?
options: With Simon a tanner by the seaside
In the temple in Jerusalem
At his own house in Caesarea
In the marketplace of Joppa
questions.correctAnswer: With Simon a tanner by the seaside
questions.explanation: Acts 10:6 tells that Peter was lodging with Simon a tanner whose house was by the seaside.

questions.question: What vision did Peter see on the housetop (Acts 10:11-12)?
options: A great sheet with all kinds of animals descending from heaven
A burning bush
A ladder reaching to heaven
A shining sword
questions.correctAnswer: A great sheet with all kinds of animals descending from heaven
questions.explanation: Acts 10:11-12 describes Peter seeing a great sheet knit at the four corners descending with many kinds of animals.

questions.question: What did the voice say to Peter about the animals in the vision (Acts 10:13)?
options: Rise, Peter; kill, and eat
Flee from these animals
Offer these animals as a sacrifice
Do not touch these animals
questions.correctAnswer: Rise, Peter; kill, and eat
questions.explanation: Acts 10:13 shows the voice commanding Peter to rise, kill, and eat the animals.

questions.question: How did Peter respond to the voice telling him to eat the animals (Acts 10:14)?
options: He said he had never eaten anything common or unclean
He immediately ate the animals
He asked for a sign
He ignored the voice
questions.correctAnswer: He said he had never eaten anything common or unclean
questions.explanation: Acts 10:14 records Peter's reply that he had never eaten anything common or unclean.

questions.question: What did the voice say after Peter refused to eat (Acts 10:15)?
options: What God hath cleansed, that call not thou common
Eat only the clean animals
Wait until the vision ends
Prepare a meal for others
questions.correctAnswer: What God hath cleansed, that call not thou common
questions.explanation: Acts 10:15 states the voice told Peter not to call common what God has cleansed.

questions.question: True or False: Cornelius fell down and worshipped Peter when he met him (Acts 10:25).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 10:25 shows Cornelius falling down at Peter's feet and worshipping him.

questions.question: True or False: Peter accepted Cornelius's worship and told him he was a divine being (Acts 10:26).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 10:26 explains that Peter told Cornelius to stand up because he himself was just a man, not divine.

questions.question: True or False: Peter said it was unlawful for a Jew to associate with someone of another nation before his vision (Acts 10:28).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 10:28 states that Peter acknowledged it was unlawful for a Jew to keep company with or visit a Gentile before God showed him otherwise.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Then Peter opened his mouth, and said, Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of _______' (Acts 10:34).
options: persons
nations
races
languages
questions.correctAnswer: persons
questions.explanation: Acts 10:34 explicitly says God is no respecter of persons, meaning He shows no partiality.

questions.question: According to Acts 10:44, what happened while Peter was speaking?
options: The Holy Ghost fell on all who heard the word
A great storm arose
The people began to sing
The temple gates opened
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Ghost fell on all who heard the word
questions.explanation: Acts 10:44 records that the Holy Ghost fell on all who heard Peter's words.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 10 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 10 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does the example of Cornelius in Acts 10 teach us about the importance of prayer and generosity in the Christian life?
options: Prayer and almsgiving are noticed by God and remembered as a memorial
Only fasting is necessary for spiritual growth
Generosity is unimportant without public recognition
Prayer should be done only privately without sharing
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer and almsgiving are noticed by God and remembered as a memorial
questions.explanation: Acts 10:2-4 shows Cornelius was devout, feared God, gave alms, and prayed continually; his prayers and alms were remembered by God, highlighting their spiritual value.

questions.question: A believer is confused about associating with those from different backgrounds. Based on Peter’s vision in Acts 10, what biblical truth would you share about God's view of people?
options: God shows no partiality and declares all clean whom He has cleansed
One should avoid all contact with those different from their own culture
Only people from the same nation are acceptable to God
Clean and unclean distinctions should always be strictly observed
questions.correctAnswer: God shows no partiality and declares all clean whom He has cleansed
questions.explanation: Acts 10:14-15 and 28 explain Peter’s vision where God commands him not to call any man common or unclean, teaching that God accepts people from every nation who fear Him and do righteousness.

questions.question: What does Cornelius’ immediate obedience to send for Peter teach us about responding to God’s guidance in our work and service?
options: Prompt obedience to God’s directions is a mark of faithfulness
Delaying obedience is acceptable if unsure
Only spiritual leaders should obey visions
Obedience should be based on personal convenience
questions.correctAnswer: Prompt obedience to God’s directions is a mark of faithfulness
questions.explanation: Acts 10:7-8 and 33 show Cornelius quickly obeyed the angel’s command to send for Peter, demonstrating trust and faithfulness in following God’s leading.

questions.question: How does Peter’s reaction to Cornelius’ worship in Acts 10 demonstrate humility in Christian leadership?
options: Peter refused worship, emphasizing he is also a man
Peter accepted worship as a sign of respect
Leaders should seek honor from others
Peter ignored Cornelius’ gesture
questions.correctAnswer: Peter refused worship, emphasizing he is also a man
questions.explanation: Acts 10:25-26 records Cornelius falling at Peter’s feet to worship, but Peter gently rebuked him, showing humility and pointing out his shared humanity.

questions.question: What biblical principle about evangelism can be learned from Peter’s willingness to go with Cornelius’ men despite cultural barriers?
options: Obeying God’s call to share the gospel transcends cultural divisions
Evangelism should be limited to one’s own people
One should only witness to those who are already believers
Sharing the gospel should be avoided if it causes discomfort
questions.correctAnswer: Obeying God’s call to share the gospel transcends cultural divisions
questions.explanation: Acts 10:20-23 shows Peter obeyed the Spirit’s command to go with the men from Cornelius, even though it was culturally unusual, teaching that God’s call to evangelize overrides human barriers.

questions.question: How does the account of the Holy Spirit falling on the Gentiles in Acts 10 encourage believers regarding God's acceptance of all people?
options: God accepts anyone who believes and receives the Holy Spirit
The Holy Spirit is given only to Jews
Gentiles are excluded from God's blessings
Only special groups receive the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: God accepts anyone who believes and receives the Holy Spirit
questions.explanation: Acts 10:44-46 shows the Holy Spirit falling on Gentiles as they heard the word, confirming that God accepts all who believe, regardless of background.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with prejudice. Based on Acts 10, what biblical truth would you share about how we should view others?
options: God shows no partiality and accepts those who fear Him and do righteousness
We should judge others by their cultural background
Only those from our own group are acceptable
Prejudice is acceptable in certain circumstances
questions.correctAnswer: God shows no partiality and accepts those who fear Him and do righteousness
questions.explanation: Acts 10:34-35 clearly states God is no respecter of persons and accepts everyone who fears Him and works righteousness, teaching believers to reject prejudice.

questions.question: According to Acts 10, what role do believers have after receiving the gospel and witnessing Christ’s resurrection?
options: To preach and testify that Jesus is appointed Judge of all
To keep the knowledge of Christ private
To wait passively for others to come to faith
To only share with those in their immediate family
questions.correctAnswer: To preach and testify that Jesus is appointed Judge of all
questions.explanation: Acts 10:42-43 explains that believers are commanded to preach and testify about Jesus being ordained Judge, emphasizing the active role in evangelism and witness.

questions.question: What does Peter’s trance and vision about unclean animals teach us about trusting God’s revelation over cultural traditions?
options: God’s commands can challenge and transform cultural practices
Cultural traditions should always override new revelations
Visions are unimportant for spiritual guidance
It is better to reject God’s word if it conflicts with customs
questions.correctAnswer: God’s commands can challenge and transform cultural practices
questions.explanation: Acts 10:9-16 records Peter’s vision where God instructs him to eat what was previously considered unclean, teaching that God's revelation can supersede cultural laws.

questions.question: How does the interaction between Cornelius and Peter model integrity and honesty in relationships within the church community?
options: They openly shared their experiences and intentions with one another
They kept their meeting secret to avoid gossip
Peter demanded payment for his visit
Cornelius hid his vision from Peter
questions.correctAnswer: They openly shared their experiences and intentions with one another
questions.explanation: Acts 10:29-33 shows Cornelius candidly explaining his vision and Peter asking the purpose of the visit, modeling honest and transparent communication.

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 10, God respects social and ethnic distinctions when accepting people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 10:34-35 teaches that God is no respecter of persons and accepts anyone who fears Him and does righteousness, regardless of social or ethnic background.

questions.question: True or False: Peter was initially certain about the meaning of his vision concerning clean and unclean animals.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 10:17 states Peter doubted in himself what the vision meant, showing initial uncertainty before God clarified its meaning.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Cornelius was a ________ who feared God, gave alms, and prayed continually.
options: centurion
king
prophet
scribe
questions.correctAnswer: centurion
questions.explanation: Acts 10:1-2 describes Cornelius as a centurion of the Italian band, who was devout and God-fearing.

questions.question: How does the command to baptize those who received the Holy Spirit in Acts 10 teach about the importance of baptism in the Christian life?
options: Baptism is an important step following receiving the Holy Spirit
Baptism is optional and unrelated to receiving the Spirit
Only certain believers should be baptized
Baptism replaces the need for the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Baptism is an important step following receiving the Holy Spirit
questions.explanation: Acts 10:47-48 shows Peter commanded baptism for those who received the Holy Spirit, emphasizing baptism as a public declaration of faith.

questions.question: What does Peter’s prayer and hunger before his vision teach us about spiritual discipline and openness to God’s teaching?
options: Spiritual discipline prepares the heart for divine revelation
Physical needs should always be prioritized over prayer
Prayer is unnecessary for receiving God’s messages
One should avoid fasting and prayer before visions
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual discipline prepares the heart for divine revelation
questions.explanation: Acts 10:9-10 shows Peter praying on the housetop and fasting, which preceded his receiving a vision, illustrating how devotion prepares believers for God’s guidance.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 10 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 10.

questions.question: What is the significance of the vision Peter received involving a sheet with various animals in Acts 10, in relation to Jewish dietary laws?
options: It signifies the abolition of all food restrictions given to Israel.
It symbolizes the inclusion of Gentiles in God's salvation plan.
It commands Peter to start a new kosher dietary system.
It foreshadows the destruction of the Temple.
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the inclusion of Gentiles in God's salvation plan.
questions.explanation: In Acts 10:11-16, the vision of the sheet with unclean animals and the command to eat indicates God declaring previously unclean people (Gentiles) as clean, symbolizing their inclusion.

questions.question: Who was Cornelius and what was his role in Acts Chapter 10?
options: A Jewish priest in Jerusalem.
A Roman centurion described as devout and God-fearing.
A Pharisee opposing Peter.
A disciple of John the Baptist.
questions.correctAnswer: A Roman centurion described as devout and God-fearing.
questions.explanation: Acts 10:1-2 describe Cornelius as a centurion of the Italian band who feared God and gave alms, highlighting his Gentile yet devout status.

questions.question: What role does the Holy Spirit play during Peter's speech to Cornelius' household?
options: The Holy Spirit falls on the Gentiles, confirming their acceptance by God.
The Holy Spirit remains silent until after the baptism.
The Holy Spirit reproves Peter for associating with Gentiles.
The Holy Spirit causes confusion among the listeners.
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Spirit falls on the Gentiles, confirming their acceptance by God.
questions.explanation: Acts 10:44-46 narrate the Holy Spirit falling on all who heard Peter's words, indicating divine approval of Gentiles receiving salvation.

questions.question: What is Peter's initial reaction to Cornelius' act of worship when they meet?
options: He accepts it with reverence.
He asks Cornelius to stand, saying he is also a man.
He rebukes Cornelius for idolatry.
He ignores Cornelius' gesture.
questions.correctAnswer: He asks Cornelius to stand, saying he is also a man.
questions.explanation: In Acts 10:25-26, Peter stops Cornelius from worshipping him, emphasizing his humanity and rejecting idolatry.

questions.question: In Acts 10, how does Peter interpret the vision about clean and unclean animals?
options: As a literal dietary command to eat all animals.
As a metaphor that no person should be called common or unclean.
As a warning against defiling the temple.
As a signal to return to Mosaic Law.
questions.correctAnswer: As a metaphor that no person should be called common or unclean.
questions.explanation: Peter realizes through the vision that God declares all people clean, breaking Jewish exclusivism (Acts 10:28).

questions.question: What is the significance of the timing of Cornelius' vision at the ninth hour in Acts 10?
options: It corresponds to the traditional time for Jewish prayer.
It marks the beginning of the Sabbath.
It is symbolic of the Passover feast.
It coincides with the daily temple sacrifice.
questions.correctAnswer: It corresponds to the traditional time for Jewish prayer.
questions.explanation: Acts 10:3 and 10:30 mention the ninth hour, which is the time for afternoon prayer, indicating Cornelius’ devoutness and God’s timely response.

questions.question: How does Peter describe God's impartiality in Acts 10?
options: God favors Jews over Gentiles.
God is no respecter of persons and accepts all who fear Him and do righteousness.
God only accepts those circumcised according to the Law.
God judges based on nationality.
questions.correctAnswer: God is no respecter of persons and accepts all who fear Him and do righteousness.
questions.explanation: Acts 10:34-35 contains Peter’s declaration that God accepts people from every nation who fear Him and do right.

questions.question: Which Old Testament concept does the idea that 'what God hath cleansed, that call not thou common' in Acts 10:15 relate to?
options: The dietary laws in Leviticus regarding clean and unclean animals.
The covenant with Abraham.
The concept of the Day of Atonement.
The Jubilee year regulations.
questions.correctAnswer: The dietary laws in Leviticus regarding clean and unclean animals.
questions.explanation: The vision relates to Levitical laws about clean and unclean animals (Leviticus 11), but here God redefines these categories to include Gentiles.

questions.question: What is the historical-cultural significance of Peter lodging with Simon the tanner in Joppa?
options: Tanners were considered ritually unclean, so Peter staying there shows breaking of purity barriers.
It was common for Jewish leaders to stay with tanners.
Tanners were wealthy and influential in Jewish society.
It was a sign of Peter’s high social status.
questions.correctAnswer: Tanners were considered ritually unclean, so Peter staying there shows breaking of purity barriers.
questions.explanation: Acts 10:6 mentions Simon the tanner; tanners handled dead animals and were ritually unclean, indicating Peter’s openness to crossing Jewish purity boundaries.

questions.question: True or False: Cornelius was a Gentile who feared God and prayed regularly, which was unusual for his cultural background.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 10:2 states Cornelius was devout, feared God, gave alms, and prayed always, unusual for a Roman centurion.

questions.question: What literary device is used in the repeated threefold command in Peter’s vision to 'kill and eat' (Acts 10:16)?
options: Chiasm
Parallelism
Repetition for emphasis
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Repetition for emphasis
questions.explanation: The command is repeated three times (Acts 10:16) to emphasize the importance of the vision's message.

questions.question: How does Peter's message in Acts 10:36-43 connect to the broader New Testament theme of Jesus as Lord?
options: It highlights Jesus as a political revolutionary.
It emphasizes Jesus as the universal Lord and Judge, confirming His resurrection and mission.
It focuses on Jesus primarily as a Jewish Messiah only.
It denies Jesus’ resurrection.
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes Jesus as the universal Lord and Judge, confirming His resurrection and mission.
questions.explanation: Acts 10:36-43 presents Jesus as Lord of all, resurrected and appointed judge, a core New Testament theme.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'God is no respecter of persons' in Acts 10:34 imply in the context of first-century Jewish-Gentile relations?
options: God judges people based on their ethnicity.
God shows favoritism to Jews only.
God accepts both Jews and Gentiles equally based on faith and righteousness.
God excludes Gentiles from salvation.
questions.correctAnswer: God accepts both Jews and Gentiles equally based on faith and righteousness.
questions.explanation: This phrase challenges Jewish exclusivism, opening salvation to Gentiles who fear God and do right (Acts 10:34-35).

questions.question: What is the significance of the Holy Spirit falling on the Gentiles before baptism in Acts 10?
options: It shows that baptism is unnecessary.
It serves as divine confirmation that Gentiles are accepted by God.
It was an accident and not significant.
It delayed the baptism until later.
questions.correctAnswer: It serves as divine confirmation that Gentiles are accepted by God.
questions.explanation: Acts 10:44-46 shows the Spirit falling on Gentiles as a sign of God's acceptance before water baptism, breaking tradition.

questions.question: Which Old Testament prophetic theme is fulfilled by Peter’s declaration that through Jesus believers receive remission of sins (Acts 10:43)?
options: The Messiah as a conquering king.
The servant of the Lord bearing sins for many (Isaiah 53).
The restoration of the Davidic kingdom only.
The rebuilding of the temple.
questions.correctAnswer: The servant of the Lord bearing sins for many (Isaiah 53).
questions.explanation: Acts 10:43 alludes to prophetic fulfillment where Jesus is the servant who brings forgiveness, echoing Isaiah 53’s suffering servant theme.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 10 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 10 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What divine attribute is illustrated by God instructing Peter not to call any man common or unclean?
options: God is impartial and shows no favoritism
God only accepts the Jews
God judges based on nationality
God excludes Gentiles from salvation
questions.correctAnswer: God is impartial and shows no favoritism
questions.explanation: Acts 10:28 and Acts 10:34 emphasize that God does not show partiality, consistent with Deuteronomy 10:17 and Romans 2:11 which affirm God's impartiality toward all people.

questions.question: How does Acts 10 reveal the universality of salvation through Jesus Christ?
options: Salvation is for everyone who fears God and does righteousness
Salvation is only for Jews
Salvation requires adherence to ceremonial law
Salvation is only through works
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation is for everyone who fears God and does righteousness
questions.explanation: Acts 10:35 teaches that in every nation, those who fear God and do righteousness are accepted by Him, echoing Old Testament promises in Isaiah 56:6-7 and New Testament affirmations in Galatians 3:28.

questions.question: What theological significance does Peter’s vision of the sheet containing all animals have?
options: It symbolizes the removal of ceremonial distinctions between clean and unclean
It shows animals are now clean for food
It commands Peter to become a vegetarian
It is a vision about dietary laws only
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the removal of ceremonial distinctions between clean and unclean
questions.explanation: Acts 10:11-16 reveals that God declares what He has cleansed is no longer common, signifying the abolition of Old Testament ceremonial distinctions, consistent with Mark 7:19 and Hebrews 10:9-10.

questions.question: What role does the Holy Spirit play in the conversion of Cornelius and his household?
options: The Holy Spirit falls upon them, confirming their acceptance by God
The Holy Spirit is not mentioned
The Holy Spirit condemns them for being Gentiles
The Holy Spirit requires circumcision before baptism
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Spirit falls upon them, confirming their acceptance by God
questions.explanation: Acts 10:44-46 shows the Holy Spirit falling on Gentile believers as a sign of divine approval, consistent with Joel 2:28 and John 7:37-39 regarding Spirit outpouring.

questions.question: What doctrinal truth is affirmed by Peter's statement that Jesus was raised on the third day?
options: The bodily resurrection of Christ as a historical fact
Jesus remained dead
Resurrection is symbolic only
Jesus rose after a week
questions.correctAnswer: The bodily resurrection of Christ as a historical fact
questions.explanation: Acts 10:40 affirms Christ's resurrection on the third day, consistent with Scriptures such as 1 Corinthians 15:3-4 and Luke 24:7, which underpin the core Christian doctrine of resurrection.

questions.question: Why did Cornelius send for Peter according to this chapter?
options: Because an angel told him to hear words from Peter
Because Peter was a political leader
Because Cornelius wanted to convert to Judaism
Because Peter was a famous teacher in Caesarea
questions.correctAnswer: Because an angel told him to hear words from Peter
questions.explanation: Acts 10:3-6 and Acts 10:22 show an angel instructed Cornelius to send for Peter to receive God's message, reflecting divine initiative in salvation (cf. Isaiah 6:8, Acts 13:2).

questions.question: What does Peter mean when he says, 'God is no respecter of persons'?
options: God does not show partiality based on ethnicity or status
God favors the Jews over Gentiles
God judges only by the law of Moses
God excludes sinners from grace
questions.correctAnswer: God does not show partiality based on ethnicity or status
questions.explanation: Acts 10:34 declares God's impartiality, consistent with Old Testament teachings such as Deuteronomy 10:17 and New Testament theology in Romans 2:11 and James 2:1.

questions.question: How does Peter’s interaction with Cornelius illustrate the breaking down of social and religious barriers?
options: Peter visits a Gentile’s house and preaches salvation to them
Peter refuses to go to Cornelius’ house
Peter preaches only to Jews
Peter enforces Jewish dietary laws strictly
questions.correctAnswer: Peter visits a Gentile’s house and preaches salvation to them
questions.explanation: Acts 10:23-28 narrates Peter's visit to Cornelius, a Gentile, showing the gospel's expansion beyond Jewish boundaries, consistent with Jesus' commission in Matthew 28:19 and Paul's teaching in Ephesians 3:6.

questions.question: What does the pouring out of the Holy Ghost on Gentiles demonstrate about the early Church’s understanding of salvation?
options: Salvation through Christ is available to all, not just Jews
Only Jews can receive the Holy Spirit
Gentiles must first become Jews
The Holy Spirit is limited to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation through Christ is available to all, not just Jews
questions.explanation: Acts 10:45 confirms the gift of the Holy Spirit on Gentiles, affirming inclusion in the covenant community, consistent with Isaiah 49:6 and Galatians 3:28.

questions.question: What is the significance of baptism in the context of Acts 10?
options: It is the public initiation into the community of believers after receiving the Holy Spirit
It is only a Jewish ritual
It is optional for Gentiles
It replaces faith in Christ
questions.correctAnswer: It is the public initiation into the community of believers after receiving the Holy Spirit
questions.explanation: Acts 10:47-48 shows that baptism follows the reception of the Holy Spirit, affirming new life in Christ, consistent with Matthew 28:19 and Romans 6:4.

questions.question: What Christological truth is proclaimed by Peter in his sermon to Cornelius’ household?
options: Jesus is Lord of all and the appointed Judge of quick and dead
Jesus is merely a prophet
Jesus is only a teacher
Jesus is a political revolutionary
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus is Lord of all and the appointed Judge of quick and dead
questions.explanation: Acts 10:36 and Acts 10:42 affirm Jesus’ lordship and role as judge, consistent with Philippians 2:9-11 and Acts 17:31.

questions.question: How does the vision of the unclean animals relate to the mission of the early Church?
options: It symbolizes the inclusion of Gentiles into the Church
It instructs dietary changes for Christians
It forbids contact with Gentiles
It is unrelated to the Church’s mission
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the inclusion of Gentiles into the Church
questions.explanation: Acts 10:11-16 symbolizes the breaking down of barriers, as God declares all people clean, which parallels the Church’s mission to preach to all nations (Matthew 28:19, Galatians 3:28).

questions.question: What is the significance of Peter’s repeated vision being shown three times?
options: It underscores the certainty and divine authority of the message
It indicates confusion in Peter
It is a sign to eat unclean animals literally
It means the vision is optional
questions.correctAnswer: It underscores the certainty and divine authority of the message
questions.explanation: Acts 10:16 shows the vision was repeated thrice, emphasizing divine confirmation, a common biblical motif for certainty (cf. Genesis 18:17-33, Exodus 34:1).

questions.question: What does Cornelius’ description as a 'devout man' who 'feared God' and gave alms imply about Gentiles before conversion?
options: Gentiles could fear God and seek Him even before knowing Christ
Gentiles were entirely pagan and ignorant
Gentiles were excluded from God's grace
Gentiles could not pray
questions.correctAnswer: Gentiles could fear God and seek Him even before knowing Christ
questions.explanation: Acts 10:2 illustrates that Gentiles like Cornelius could be devout and God-fearing, consistent with Old Testament examples like Melchizedek (Genesis 14:18) and New Testament teachings about God’s revelation to all (Romans 1:19-20).

questions.question: What apologetic purpose does the conversion of Cornelius serve in the early Church?
options: It validates that the gospel is for Gentiles as well as Jews
It restricts salvation to Jewish believers only
It discourages Gentiles from joining the Church
It supports maintaining Jewish ceremonial law for all
questions.correctAnswer: It validates that the gospel is for Gentiles as well as Jews
questions.explanation: Acts 10 as a whole defends the inclusion of Gentiles, countering objections to Gentile inclusion in the Church, consistent with Paul's defense in Galatians 2:7-9 and Peter's vision in Acts 11:18.
